abstract.p: This article investigates the effects of different steering geometries on the steering response, system stability and frequency response of bicycles. A computer model was developed using Simulink™. The model simulates different bicycle designs allowing several different steering geometries to be quantified in terms of performance. It was validated by data available in literature and from an experimental investigation conducted with a bicycle fitted with steering and roll sensors. Three key variables were examined in detail: the head tube angle, front fork rake and bicycle speed. Their actual importance was determined by systematically changing each key variable one at a time while keeping all other terms constant. Large variations in roll and yaw responses show how sensitive bicycles are to small changes in head tube angles and rake dimensions. At higher speeds, the observed steering responses support the common observation that bicycles are more stable and easier to ride at higher speeds. These simulations show the importance of correctly designing a bicycle’s steering geometry in order to optimise steering performance and the sensitivity of bicycles to small changes in geometry.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Research into bicycle dynamics has been evolving for many years, yet many questions still need to be resolved.1–3 The bicycle has been in existence for over a century but yet many mysteries surround the bicycle. Upon reflection, the bicycle is a deceptive object as it looks simple and yet it isn’t.4 Of particular interest is the question of how a bicycle’s steering remains stable, this needs further understanding and analysis.5

One early explanation of the stability of a bicycle in motion was proposed in 1869 by Rankine who argued that centrifugal forces resulted in sufficient torque to balance the gravitational overturning moment.6 Timoshenko and Young7 showed how this balance was possible with a short analysis of bicycle motion. They described a mathematical model for a bicycle which was similar to the balancing of an inverted pendulum. The rider steers the bicycle in such a way as to use centrifugal forces to position the centre of mass over the tyres and so to correct for any capsize tendency.

The role of gyroscopic effects in bicycle stability is often misunderstood and overstated.8 Jones9 was the first to demonstrate the relative unimportance of gyroscopic effects. A special bicycle was built with a second wheel fitted next to the existing front wheel. It was linked to the front wheel so that it is rotated at the same speed but in the opposite direction and it did not touch the ground. As the second wheel was nearly identical to the original front wheel, much of the gyroscopic effect was cancelled. It was found to be a simple matter to ride this ‘zero gyroscopic’ bicycle and its handling did not substantially differ from an unmodified bicycle.

Jones also examined the basic question of why it is possible to keep a bicycle upright and why it seems easier to maintain balance when riding at some speed. This researcher analysed the well-known observation that a bicycle front wheel turns into the direction of any roll (i.e. into the corner). The front wheel gravitational torque that produces this roll is caused by gravity acting on the front wheel mass to lower its height. Jones proposed a steering stability parameter based on ‘dH2/dα dL’ (subsequently called the Jones Index, where H is the height of the hub, α the head tube angle and L the wheelbase). The experimental work of Jones has been widely referred to by later researchers.10–13

Other researchers have developed alternative models of bicycle dynamics including the study of sudden cornering manoeuvres. Lowell and McKell11 used Timoshenko and Young’s analysis, but simplified their equations by only considering small angles of roll and steer. Jackson and Dragovan14 developed similar equations to Lowell and McKell, but allowed for more realistic steering geometries. They also completed some experimental work which measured the actual motion of a bicycle.

Cossalter et al.15 described a detailed mathematical model for the steady-state turning of a two-wheeled motorcycle. Steady-state turning assumes that both the roll angle and the steering angle remain constant. Their model was complex, consisting of four distinct rigid bodies that made up the motorcycle and allowed for tyre effects, aerodynamic effects and pitching.

Meijaard and Popov16 also developed a model for a motorcycle including a tyre model, aerodynamic forces, suspension and power train and proportional–integral rider control action. Their results described the interaction of many of these components; for example, the aerodynamic forces tend to damp the wobble mode but accentuate the weave mode.16

Fajans10 described the equations of motion for bicycles and motorcycles in detail and explained the phenomena of counter-steer cornering. Counter-steer cornering occurs when the steering wheel is initially turned away from the desired direction of turn causing the bicycle to roll into the corner due to centrifugal effects. His results were similar to Jackson and Dragovan and he also concluded that gyroscopic terms were unimportant.

Astrom et al.17 developed several increasingly complex bicycle models. Their final model included front wheel steering angle and trail terms but neglected the stabilising effects of the front fork and any gyroscopic effects.17

Meijaard et al.18 developed linearised equations of motion for a rigid four body bicycle system that included typical front wheel geometry. They validated their theoretical approach with two different computer simulations and compared their results to those of others.

Sharma and Umashankar19 designed a fuzzy controller for a bicycle system using the equations developed by Lowell and McKell.11 Their computer simulation of their controller displayed marginal stability with steady oscillations of the steering and lean angles. One of their equations appeared to contain a sign error and as their results did not display any counter-steering action, it is thought that their investigation contained errors.

Lignoski20 completed an interesting experiment to determine if the steering angle is proportional to the lean angle. This is an assumption made by several researchers to simplify their equations of motion.11,19 Lignoski’s experiment while ingenuous appears inconclusive and made a tentative conclusion only that the steering angle is proportional to the lean angle (the constant of proportionality k = 2.40 ± 0.15).

Ringwood and Feng21 wrote an interesting paper examining front wheel instability at high speed. They used Astrom et al.’s bicycle model and spent some time obtaining experimental values for important variables from actual road bicycles. They described the pole variations for different conditions and made several suggestions as to the causes of instability and possible cures.

Several investigators developed a motorcycle model using Cossalter et al.’s15 and Sharp’s2 equations.22 Ten different packages were developed using the Modelica library, including packages for the road environment and the driver. This could perform virtual prototyping for actual motorcycle designs and could be adapted for bicycles.

Moore and Hubbard looked at the importance of front wheel diameter, head tube angle, trail and wheelbase on the self-stability of a bicycle. They used a mathematical model that they benchmarked to Meijaard et al’s18 equations and considered the bicycle’s self-stability only with no piloting or control action by the rider. The model included a rider as a rigid body with no piloting action. They considered a narrow speed range of 12.9–17.6 km/h and two instability modes, capsize and weave. An interesting and unexpected result was obtained that the stable speed range was close to the minimum value when the front wheel diameter was 680 mm (close to the standard road bicycle wheel diameter of a 700C wheel).23 Furthermore, Kooijman et al.24 conducted a series of interesting experiments involving an instrumented rider and bicycle on the road and on a large treadmill and concluded that the rider steers and stabilises the bicycle mainly by steering inputs with very little upper body lean.

While it is clear that certain myths about bicycle motion still persist, many questions about bicycle dynamics and control have been answered in the past 20 years using equations independently formulated to describe the important external and internal torques acting on a bicycle when it is cornering.17,18 It has also been established by several researchers that the inverted pendulum model gives a good explanation of bicycle stability in terms of the sideways capsize.7 Many researchers have shown conclusively that gyroscopic effects cannot account for the stability of bicycles and various explanations for the increased stability or rideability of individual bicycles at higher speeds have been proposed.4,7,9,11

This article examines the question of how changes in steering geometry affect bicycle dynamics. By developing a computer model of a bicycle, the effect of different steering geometries, steering inputs and speeds were examined. The model was compared to an experimental investigation.

sec.title: Model formulation
sec.p:
A bicycle consists of at least six rigid bodies: the front wheel, front forks and handlebars, main frame, rear wheel, lower and the upper parts of rider. However, the bicycle can be approximated as two bodies or assemblies A and B, see Figure 1.10 Assembly ‘A’ consists of the front wheel, the front forks and the handlebars. These all turn and move together with one exception, the front wheel rotates about its hub axle. The other assembly ‘B’ consists of the main triangular frame, the rear wheel and the rider. The frame and the rear wheel move together as one unit except for the rotation of the rear wheel about its hub axle. Despite the rider not being a fixed body, it is a common practice to treat the rider as a rigid body fixed to the frame.10,11,14 Figure 1.
The bicycle model split into assemblies A and B.

Using the above approach, the following assumptions are implemented in this study.
The bicycle consists of two rigid body assemblies A and B with the principal axes of inertia for each body lying along vertical and horizontal planes, i.e. they coincide with the reference axes XA–YA–ZA and XB–YB–ZB, see Figures 1 and 2.
The rider is part of assembly B and is assumed to be rigid and therefore the centre of mass of B does not move.
A three-axes coordinate system for the bicycle model about the three separate centres of gravity is shown in Figure 2.
The Coriolis effects of the front and rear assemblies are included.
The bicycle frame, front forks and both wheels are all rigid structures and do not distort in shape.
All aerodynamic forces on bicycle and rider are ignored.
The road is smooth, level and uncambered.
The bicycle is travelling at a constant speed, is not pitching or bouncing, and the roll and steering angles are both small, i.e. less than 10°.
The tyres are thin, do not distort, slip sideways when cornering or slip in the direction of travel.
The rider applies the steering torque as a pure couple and the bicycle undertakes a counter-steer cornering manoeuvre.
The front tyre, rear tyre and centre of mass turn through the same radius when cornering.
The radius of cornering is much larger than the bicycle wheelbase.
Realistic steering geometry can be used, i.e. the fork rake and head tube angle can be varied.
Figure 2.
The three-axes coordinate bicycle system.

This bicycle model is essentially two dimensional and only considering changes in roll and yaw. This is only acceptable for cornering action up to a centrifugal acceleration of 0.3 g.25,26 In this model, the maximum cornering accelerations are in the order of 0.26 g.

Most of the above assumptions are self-explanatory; however, to justify assumption 9, many researchers of road bicycles have assumed that the wheels to be thin discs and ignored any tyre effects.10,11,17,18 Further, using an instrumented bicycle on a rolling road, it has been concluded that: The most dubious assumption that was validated in this model (referring to their maths model18) was the replacement of the tyres by knife edge wheels rolling without slipping.27 On the other hand, tyre models have been considered for motorcycles.15,22,28 Given that road bicycle tyres are smaller in width and operate at higher inflation pressures, it is reasonable to assume that they distort less and can be modelled as thin discs. However, previous work has indicated that the model requires some dampening for stability. Thus, in this study, tyre damping effect is included by adding a dampening term in the model.

Longitudinal wheel slip (in the direction of travel) has been ignored as it is assumed that such slip only occurs when braking or accelerating.29 Sideways tyre friction is present in the model and is essential in order for the bicycle to corner and to be stable. However, the current model ignores tyre rolling resistance as it is assumed that the speed is constant.

This article assumes that the human rider to be a rigid body attached solidly to the rear frame (all of which is called assembly B). Kooijman et al.24 have demonstrated that the rider steers and stabilises the bicycle mainly by steering inputs with very little upper body lean. Therefore, no pedalling action and no counterbalancing using the rider’s torso, which is called hip flick,10 was considered. However, the only piloting aspect of the human rider in this article is the simple steering torque action as described in the graph in Figure 6. Figure 3.

These equations are similar to Fajans,10 but have additional terms (they allowed for the Coriolis effect, steering head tube angle and effective trail) added to allow for the steering geometry. See Tables 1 to 4, Figure 3 and Appendix for a complete definition of these terms. One of main objectives of this study is to investigate the significance of these additional terms. Table 1.
Terms in equation (1).

All the torques in equations (1) to (3) are self-explanatory except for the kink torque. If the front wheel is turned, both wheel contact points follow arcs, while the rear wheel trajectory smoothly transitions into a curved path the front wheel trajectory has a kink. Likewise, the trajectory of the point halfway between the wheels has a similar kink resulting in the kink torque term. Fajans described the kink torque as being valid in a reference frame rotating at the instantaneous angular frequency V/R = (V/L) x σ.10

The governing equations of motion (1) to (3) were used to formulate a mathematical model for bicycle dynamic motion which was solved using Simulink™ in a MATLAB® environment. Different inputs such as riding conditions and bicycle geometry were used in the model to quantify the effect these variables have on the dynamic behaviour. An important feature of this model was the ability to use different steering geometries in order to achieve optimum steering performance.

sec.title: Model validation
sec.p: Two approaches were adopted to validate this model’s equations. First, a simplified Simulink™ model was prepared that used the same assumptions as Fajans.10 This was done by setting the terms allowing for the Coriolis effect and steering head tube angle to zero. The modified model showed identical results to Fajans in terms of yaw versus time and roll versus time, with identical time lags, rise times, amplitudes, overshoots and oscillations.10

Next, a bicycle was built to conduct further investigations. The bicycle was fitted with transducers to measure steering and roll angles and a data logger was used to record the results. In a series of experimental trials, the bicycle was ridden over normal city streets and level car park surfaces. The roll angle was measured using a custom made infrared (IR) distance measuring sensor mounted on a short bracket at the rear of the bicycle. A pulse of IR light was emitted from the sensor and travelled downwards, as it hits the road surface it reflects back. Any reflected IR light returned to the sensor at a slightly different angle from the transmitted angle and the angle of the returning IR light was proportional to the distance to the road surface. As the bicycle rolled, the IR sensor detected changes in its distance from the ground and this was used to calculate the roll angle, see Figures 4 to 6. One practical problem experienced was the measurement noise caused due to the road surface roughness. This is one area that needs improvement in future work.

The steering angle was measured using a rotary electrical potentiometer with its input shaft directly attached to the steering stem by a simple coupling. The potentiometer’s output was proportional to the front wheel’s steering angle. The experimental data obtained showed a set of dynamic responses with the same characteristics of the model, see Figure 6. Details of these devices including information on their specifications are listed in Table 6.

The experimental procedure consisted of counter-steer cornering manoeuvres and road runs under various conditions. The best experimental results obtained were on a smooth road surface and showed repeatable counter-steered cornering behaviour. The results showed the same characteristics for roll and yaw predicted by the computer simulation. The counter-steered manoeuvre was always preceded by the telltale yaw of the front wheel in the opposite direction to the turn, followed by a quick yaw reversal as the turn continued. It was also noted that the same effect occurred during the correcting part of the manoeuvre as the bicycle came back onto a straight course, see Figures 7 and 8. Figure 7.
The steering angle output for an experimental counter-steer manoeuvre. Figure 8.
The roll angle output for an experimental counter-steer cornering manoeuvre.

In principle, this study aims to look at the trend (e.g. the counter-steering action) and it was very difficult to statistically correlate the data due to the irregular road surface and the measurement noise that resulted. However, the results of the experiments and the comparison with other work10 indicate that the present computer model is acceptable to study bicycle dynamics.

sec.title: Significance of added terms
sec.p:
One key objective of this investigation was to investigate the significance of several additional terms added to allow for the steering geometry. Their actual importance was determined by systematically changing one key variable at a time while keeping all other terms constant. The following three key variables were examined in detail:
head tube angle (Φ), changed from 71–80°;
rake (β), changed from 15 to 75 mm; and
the speed (v), varied from 5 to 50 km/h.

In this series of simulations, the benchmark bicycle parameters were a head tube angle of 73°, a rake of 45 mm and a speed of 25 km/h (6.944 m/s). These values are typical of road bicycles and were selected after consulting the literature. It is claimed that such geometry has been found by trial and error to give good steering behaviour.3

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The roll and yaw responses for a bicycle with standard parameters are shown in Figure 9. In all cases, a standard steering torque input (+0.45 and −0.414 Nm) was used to perform the counter-steer manoeuvre, see Figure 10. Figure 9.
The roll and yaw responses for a bicycle with standard parameters. Figure 10.
The standard steering torque used to perform all simulations.

First, the head tube angle was altered in steps from 71° to 80°. From Figures 11 and 12, it can be seen that for the standard angle of 73°, there is a reasonably quick response with small overshoots and a short settling time. When the angle was reduced to 71°, the settling time increased by 40% and the overshoot by 100% as both the yaw and roll became unstable and the bicycle became unrideable. When the angle was then increased to 80°, the overshoot increased beyond 300%. The large changes in roll and yaw responses show how sensitive bicycles are to small changes in head tube angles. Figure 11.
Roll responses for bicycles with head tube angles from 71° to 80°. Figure 12.
Yaw responses for bicycles with head tube angles from 71° to 80°.

Next, the rake was changed from 15 to 75 mm (i.e. effective trail 83.68 and 23.68 mm, respectively). From Figures 13 and 14, it can be seen that the standard rake of 45 mm (effective trail 53.68 mm) gave a reasonably quick response with small overshoots and a short settling time. Decreasing the rake resulted in an immediate increase in settling time of over 200% at 35 mm rake, and at rakes 25 and 15 mm, both the yaw and roll became unstable. Increasing the rake up to 75 mm, however, resulted in a 400% increase in overshoot. Figure 13.
Roll responses for bicycles with rake values ranging from 15 to 75 mm. Figure 14.
Yaw responses for bicycles with rake values ranging from 15 to 75 mm.

Finally, speed changes were examined to see if a bicycle is more stable at higher speeds, see Figures 15 and 16. At 5 km/h, the bicycle was unstable for the standard steering torque input. At higher speeds, the response to the same steering torque became progressively smaller supporting the common observation that bicycles are less sensitive to steering inputs and hence more stable and easier to ride at higher speeds. Figure 15.
Roll responses for bicycles at speeds ranging from 5 to 50 km/h. Figure 16.
Roll responses for bicycles at speeds ranging from 5 to 50 km/h.

At speeds of 50 km/h, aerodynamic drag plays a significant role, particularly against the rider’s frame and in any cornering against the front projected area of the wheel/fork assembly. The implication of ignoring this effect is that the top speed of 50 km/h was only considered to examine the question of whether stability was improved at higher speeds. If windage had been included, it would be reasonable to assume it as a constant force (as the speed is assumed to be constant) from nearly constant direction (as any change in direction was small) and hence any resulting torque would be small and therefore its effect as a torque would be minimal. The assumption for this model is that the yaw and roll angles are less than 10°. At 15 km/h, the yaw angle is 8.6° and at 50 km/h it drops to 0.6°.

These three series of simulations show the importance of correctly selecting a bicycle’s steering geometry in order to optimise steering performance and the sensitivity of bicycles to small changes in geometry.

The validation showed that following terms in the new bicycle model are significant and should be considered. The front wheel gravitational and castor torque and steering torque input are significant terms in equation (1) and do determine the model characteristics. The damping torque in equation (1) is small but should not be ignored because it has a significant effect on stability. In equation (2), two new significant terms, the front wheel gravitational and castor torque, are added due to considerations of the steering geometry. In equation (3), the gravitational and centrifugal torques are large and must be included.

It is also concluded that the following terms are minor and their effect can be ignored. For equation (1), the gyroscopic torque of the front wheel due to rolling, the Coriolis torque of assembly A and the torque B exerts on A are minor. In equation (2), the inertia torque of assembly A due to rolling and the new steering torque term added due to steering geometry considerations can be ignored. Finally, equation (3) has two minor terms, the inertia torque of assembly B due to rolling and the kink torque. It can be seen that as stated by many previous researchers the gyroscopic terms are insignificant and cannot account for bicycle stability.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
This research successfully developed a computer model for bicycle motion which can be used to study performance in terms of steering response, roll motion and steering wheel stability. The addition of steering geometry adds important terms which have a significant effect on steering performance.
